reviewText: Volume 5 of Architectures is a review of six buildings each coming from different concepts, some of the concepts have their orgin in religion, one from neoclassical followers, and others are purely conceptual. The Alhambra Grenada constructed in the 14th century by an Arab ruler, emphazizes the palace, pools and geometic decorations. After Charles V took contol of Grenada there was a plan to redo some of the design features,some of the features changed to portray Christians beliefs. The House of Sugimoto, built more on the Japanese belief system and of the garden concept with spaces designated for special vistors, dining, and etc. Walls of paper and wood that allows different use of different areas, space in the important concept in this building, the rooms when not in use are empty. The ambitious building period started in 1937 by Mussolini who sort to rid Rome of past designs and made a grand effort toward modernity. The Yoyogi Olympic Gymansiums were built for the 1964 Olyamics Games in Tokyo a complete departure to a very abstract design. The Villa Barbaro, a country home built and designed by Palladio, representing the neoclassical period. Phaeno, A public place to be used as scientific involvement by the people. This is an excellent DVD tracing classical architectural designs into the modernity era of building forms. SPR Design and Color in Islamic Achitecture: Afganistan, Iran, Turkey. Arquitectura industrial en Espana, 1830-1990/ Industrial Achitecture in Spain, 1830-1990 (Cuadernos Arte Catedra) (Spanish Edition) Women in Achitecture a Contemporary PerspectiveArchitecture: Form, Space, and Order
